hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: I absolutely love the Prince Gallery! I’ve stayed at this property over 15 times, and it’s become my go-to hotel in Tokyo.When I checked in over the weekend, I was told that as an Ambassador Elite member (Marriott’s highest level) I no longer have access to the club lounge. I now have to pay for a special club floor room in order to gain access. This is absolutely absurd. The club lounge is one of the key reasons I choose to stay at The Prince Gallery, and is one of the key benefits of elite membership across the SPG/Marriott portfolio.I don’t think I will stay at the Prince Gallery again, now that these key benefits have been revoked. Reading through the other reviews, it sounds like several other elites are also choosing to stay at other properties as a result of the change. The hotel needs to realize that this very poor business decision is driving away their most loyal customers. I really hope they re-think this policy, but until they do, I will be staying at other Tokyo hotels.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: This downtown hotel has a looby bar to die for with views that go for miles. But the rooms are where it all happens. The bathroom has auto fogging glass walls and a toilet seat that lifts itself. the lights have coordinated mood settings and the drapes are automatic. every aspect is an architectural masterpiece. Don't miss the gift shop with Japanese luxury items for purchase. All you have to do is GO! DJ

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: I stayed at this hotel for 5 times since it opened, and was quite impressed by it:- While base rooms are on the small side for the price it charges, deluxe rooms are very well-appointed with a breathtaking view of Tokyo. - Service was generally good. English level was reasonably well.- Buffet breakfast at the restaurant was mediocre and the restaurant is often busy but Japanese breakfast is excellent.- Club lounge offering was nice and offers a good, quieter alternative for having breakfasts.- Although not located exactly in the popular tourist areas, many major tourist spots in Tokyo are at an acceptable distance by metro which is easily accessible from the hotel.After my first stay a couple of years ago I was so satisfied with the hotel that it became my "go-to" hotel in Tokyo, despite the rather high prices it charges given its location. Now I have second thoughts after learning that the hotel has made significant cutbacks to Marriott Bonvoy elite benefits without prior announcements, including club lounge access and the so-called "special" breakfast menus for elites which mean extra charges for an omelette or a Japanese breakfast.Explanation given by the hotel on other recent reviews regarding lounge access is ridiculous as if they were forced by corporate to remove such benefit. It was clearly a cost-cutting move. As for breakfast, I would accept it if non-elite guests booking breakfast-inclusive rates were required the pay the surcharge for a Japanese breakfast, but it appears not to be the case. The concept of this "special" menu to elites is simply insulting to loyal guests like myself - I cannot understand why a high-end Japanese hotel would charge loyal guests only for sampling Japanese food.Luckily I learnt such changes before I book my next stay in Tokyo, and I feel sorry for those elite members who book the hotel without knowing such changes.To be honest, without such extra benefits for elites, the hotel does not quite worth the price it has been charging, especially that I could be (and had been) assigned to standard rooms with only 35sqm. With no lounge access, long queues at breakfast restaurant and a "special" breakfast menu, there is no point to spend that money to stay here.It was the extra mile the hotel used to go to for elite members which made me return again and again. With the hotel not recognizing loyalty by offering the bare minimum, I can no longer convince myself to keep staying at this hotel anymore. This is a point which the hotel management who proposed (and poorly executed) such changes seems to miss (or not to bother). While this review from a once-loyal guest is unlikely to change anything, I would urge other fellow Marriott elite members to re-consider whether they should stay at a hotel which does not recognize loyalty other than shamelessly repeating that they still offer the bare minimum.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: Beautiful Hotel with well designed, comfortable rooms.However the service was not 5 star and not the famous Japanese politeness. We arrived at 11.00am after travelling from the skifields and were told to come back @ 2pm to check in. Absolutely fine. BUT when we returned at 4.30 we were told one of our rooms (we had 2 rooms at @ $750 each) was not ready. The reason was a late check out by the previous occupant. Since when is a 4.45 checkin acceptable? Why is someone given a late checkout when the room is booked?. Then they gave us some extras to make up for it but that is all too late. All we wanted was check in at the proper time. Breakfast is good, position is convenient.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: I really wanted to like this hotel. I'm Marriott loyal but usually stay at the Grand or Park Hyatts in Tokyo. Though the views from the bar and room are excellent, it went downhill quickly upon check in for my 1 night stay. After walking in to a crowded lobby, we stood in line for about 10 minutes. Then my passport was taken and it was another 20 minutes of sitting. During this time, I noticed my passport, open, on a clipboard of a receptionist running around the lobby. Once they finally got to me, my Platinum status was barely recognized, except to have me choose between breakfast or extra points. I chose breakfast (imporant for later). I was sent on my way to my quite small room on the same floor as the lobby. Room: The room is ultra modern, to a fault. Shower in the middle of the room with button that "frosts" the glass is cool if staying alone or with a partner. Ipad controls everything. It was missing any kind of Japanese touch that I've had in other luxury hotels. Size was also smaller than other Tokyo hotels I've stayed. Lounge: **NOTICE TO MARRIOTT STATUS MEMBERS** Lounge access is no longer granted, something that started the day before we arrived. We were "grandfathered" in and granted lounge access, though this turned out to be nothing special. From 5-7 they serve drinks, though its limited. No hot food options, and a limited selection of canapes. In addition to the lounge attendant being almost dismissive, they were out of everything. We had to ask for forks, then glasses, then water. It was disappointing. Breakfast: The breakfast incident is what ultimately drops the hotel from 3 to 2. I asked 3 different people in the morning where to have platinum breakfast. All of them said the all day dining restaurant. At 9:30 I waited for 20 minutes to be seated with my 3 friends. The 4 of us then waited another 15 minutes for a server. I asked the server again to confirm, this was the restaurant to have platinum breakfast. She radioed to the host, who said I was not platinum and did not have included breakfast. I produed the Marriott app that showed my status, and she persisted I don't have breakfast included. At this point I started to get mad, and she indicated a front desk agent would come to speak with me. Once the agent arrived, he explained something to the effect that I, despite having the same status as my friends, did not have breakfast, though everyone else did. I pushed. He indicated I must have been told incorrectly at check in, though my friends were told the same thing, and again, had breakfast included with the same status. They ultimately somehow realized their mistake and included breakfast, but this was another 20 min of waiting. We're at nearly an hour now, without any coffee or food. The breakfast buffet includes an egg dish ordered of the menu, mine came cold, one of my friends never came. The buffet was missing many items and not restocked as we were running to the end of breakfast (after waiting an hour). All told, it took more than 90 minutes to have a really subpar breakfast, and I had to head to the airport shortly after. I checked out shortly after, was not asked how the stay was, how I liked anything, just given a bill. A taxi was called, and I was glad to be leaving. In my opinion hotels in Japan live and die on their service. The Prince Gallery missed the mark here, and I'll be returning to a Hyatt next time I'm in Tokyo.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: It was our most pleasant stay for the price we paid and the service we received.We would like to take this chance to thank the night shift staffs who escorted us at night. My brother was very ill and in need of a list of certain medicines for cold and sore throat. As I must stay to assist my sick brother in the room, I made a call to hotel staff. At first I was rejected by the staff to help in purchasing the drugs outside, so I asked the other female staff who happened to be delivering the cosmetics to me at the time. She did me a big favor by communicating to other staffs to help buying the medicine at Don Quijote (at my own expense). Later we received the medicine together with changes and receipt, and a thermometer provided by the hotel. The staff's honesty and eager were very impressive. I felt grateful to all staffs involved. Definitely have a second visit!The beds, linens, pajamas, and pillows were very comfortable. I loved the hair dryer to the point that I searched to buy it back home. If you are looking for a reasonably priced 5-star hotel, I suggest here - The Prince Hotel Tokyo Kioicho. Japanese staffs speak English quite well but there is also an American concierge in case of any difficulty in communication.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: It its a great luxury hotel in Tokyo and was one of my favourite options in town, especially considering the great recognition of elite guests from Marriott. Seems like the hotel is now going in a different direction. Since last week, no more lounge access for Platinum guests; the breakfast option is really poor (just very basic and no alternatives), and also they stopped the option to use Suite Night Awards to members. This are really bad changes and I will cancel all incoming stays and will not return back to The Prince Gallery.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: I was informed that the hotel no longer provides club lounge access to Marriott Bonvoy Platinum or Titanium elite guests. To add insult to injury the breakfast offered to elites now is only a continental breakfast (coffee, juice, breads) and no longer full buffet or Japanese breakfast. This is totally a bait & switch scam as I made my reservation several weeks prior to my stay when the hotel was still providing club lounge access and full breakfast to Platinum elites. I regret my choice to stay at this hotel and would have chosen to stay at a a different property that value the loyalty of Marriott elite members.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: I was very excited to stay at TPG, as I had read a lot of Amazing reviews on it! So, as soon as I started planning our Japan trip, TPG was definitely a must! The check in desk is at the very top floor, and the rooms are actually placed below the check in floor. You are greeted right away, and the staff is very polite and always on hand to help. The rooms are AMAZING! They give you an ipad that lets you control all the fixtures and mechanics of the room, from Lighting to temperature. However, my favorite part has to be the see thru shower, with the fog light. The rainfall shower and the stone tub makes you feel like Royalty! They also offer so many amenities in your room, from sweet smelling soaps, bath salts, even a weight scale! They also gave us complimentary chocolates and a guide book. The beds are very comfortable and the walls are thick so I wasn't distracted by loud neighbors. I was fortunate enough to experience the "Traditional Japanese Breakfast" in their lounge, where they presented me with an almost doll house-like box of goodies. I loved every minute of my stay here. The only downside was that I wasn't able to use the spa/pool facilities because I have a little tattoo on my neck. However, I would definitely come and stay here again, just for the experience.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: The moment you step into the lobby at the 36th floor, you would be wowed by the view from the illumiid bar. This hotel was opened about 2 years ago, and it is located in the center of Tokyo above a complex with supermarket, restaurants, and coffee shops. It is also connected to subway station so it is convenient to access to the whole Tokyo. Since it is in the center of Tokyo, and high floor, the hotel has stunning and expanded views of Tokyo. After check in the reception staff ) will take you to your room and introduce the high tech accessories and the room. The curtain and lighting can be controoled with an iPad, and I love that their shower amenities which are made by Byredo. Miss Chiang is the staff who serviced us, and she is very professional and friendly. Maybe because the hotel is located close to the prime minister's residence, the security is very strict, you have to swipe your room key twice before accessing to the guest rooms. As a Marriott PPE member (now titanium status), we were able to access the club lounge and enjoyed complimentary breakfast at the Souten restaurant (other options are Oasis restaurant and the club lounge). The Japanese style breakfast at Souten restaurant was one of the best I have ever had in any hotels. Let's talk about the club lounge. It was a little bit crowded at the happy hour in the lounge, and they arranged us to be seated in the gallery suite close to the club lounge. The suite has a spectacular view of the Imperial Palace to the Skytree. We had a great talk with Mr. Usami, the lounge manager. Mr. Usami was very attentive to bring us food and drink since we were not in the lounge but in the suite room as a temporary lounge space. The stay in Prince Gallery Kioi is like too good to be true, I was hesitating writing the review because I was worried that I cannot get a room here next time. Thanks to all the staff serviced us during our stay so that we had such a great experience.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: The floor to ceiling windows and the high floor for the lobby and rooms make the views absolutely breathtaking, perhaps none more so than the entry to the lobby looking down on the bar and Tokyo. The rooms were excellently appointed, modern yet minimalist. It is a new hotel, roughly 2 years old. The service was very good and the gym was very nice, as well. We had access to the Club Lounge which had a fabulous morning breakfast in a relaxing environment. There are many restaurants, convenience stores, and night entertainment establishments within 5-10 minutes walking and the New Otani has a nice bar across the street. I think this is an undiscovered gem!

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: I stayed at this hotel for 2 nights in the first week of Feb. I was very lucky to be upgraded to Grand Deluxe Corner King room. The view from the room was spectacular! I enjoyed so much taking a bath and overseeing Tokyo at night. The room was also clean and tidy. Breakfast was good, although food selection could be improved. Hospitality was one of the best I had in my life. Every staff is professional and sincere.The turndown service made me feel coming home every night. Overall, truly an unforgettable experience. Highly recommended!

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: I decided to try the club level rooms here and i was a little disappointed when comparing the club lounge to the club lounge at the prince park tower. The prince park tower club lounge was far superior. The club lounge is more exclusive at the prince park tower. It seemed this lounge was full of businessman using a spg upgrade to get to the club level instead of paying the 500 to 700 dollars a night to get club level at the prince park tower. As a result the quality of food and liquor was inferior. The major upside was that the club lounge staff spoke excellent english and were very helpful. There were things i liked about the hotel such as the views and the quality of rooms and proximity to a subway station. The breakfast was horrible and service horrible. If you want excellent service and a great breakfast stay at the prince park tower but dont expect any kind of upgrade. They dont care how many nights you stay or have stayed. Lastly at the club level if you stay more than three days in a row you have access to the hotel limousine free of charge.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: I have found a new favourite hotel in Asia! Brilliant foyer and a spectacular view of the city made more special at night. Very innovative design.The rooms are a bit larger than normal Tokyo fair, elegant and well appointed with excellent bath amenities. Sufficient workspace and plugs for charging etc.The staff were all outstanding, attentive, polite, and well spoken which is standard for a 5 star property, but they exceeded expectations on this trip.The food was also excellent, although if I had one critique it would be the main restaurant was quite small and we could not get in at lunch for a business meeting because we had failed to book - make a note.The Executive Lounge was stunning and a great place to relax, well appointed but perhaps a bit more variety of food could be considered.All in all a brilliant hotel. A bit more on the expensive side, but compared to other “luxury” 5 stars, our rate was very competitive.A must stay and looking forward to coming back on a family visit.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: After having a great experience staying at The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho last year, I decided to stay again this year. And it was a great decision. The stay was as great as before.Check in and check out was very efficient as before. And as a Platinum Premier member at Marriott Rewards I receive a nice room upgrade. This time I manage to try the breakfast offering at Oasis Garden.It was good and definitely can become a very good options for people who not really like to have breakfast in the lounge.  Arrange an airport transfer to Haneda, and again it was handled very well. Definitely will choose The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho again for my future stays.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: Impeccable service, wonderful beds, breathtaking views, state of the art anemities, central location. Nothing more to say. Dream hotel. I’m almost afraid to write this review in fear of it not being available for my next trip.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: This is my second time staying at this hotel, and this is truly a 5 star service hotel. My review below is using my recent Ritz Carlton Kyoto and St Regis Osaka stay as the benchmark. Facility: The hotel facility is just as beautiful and new as I remembered when they first opened back in 2016. The design of the hotel is simple and elegant. Unlike most hotels where you notice tear and wear even after a few years, this hotel is very well maintained. Everything is iPad controlled. The hotel lobby and bar has an amazing view of the Tokyo tower. For whisky lovers, the bar has a solid selection of Japanese whisky, prices are in alignment to other upscale hotels. Rooms: the room is spacious based on Tokyo standard. Everything is controlled via iPad similar to most hotels. The only challenge I have is that this hotel doesn’t appear to accept suite upgrade certificates, I spoke to a Marriott representative and this has more to do with the fact these are luxury collections. Hopefully with the new loyalty program, this gets sorted out. Location: this hotel has two popular subway station right across the street from the hotel. I opted to stay here because of its central and in the middle of where I wanted to go. There is tons of restaurants in the alley behind the BIC camera which is less than 5 minutes walk from the hotel. We arrived here at close to mid-night and after dropping off our luggage, we went to eat. Lots of good Izakaya, ramen and gyoza options that are open late.Service: the hotel goes beyond and above to help their guests. For example, I needed to purchase foam to package the Japanese whisky I bought in Tokyo. Miss. Tanaka from the front desk provided me the store address (taking into consideration where I was planning to go to make this detour convenient), but in addition to that, she located the floor where the product would likely be stored. And wrote in a note for me in Japanese the name of the product so that I can show the store employees what it is I am looking for in case I can’t find it myself. Another example, the concierge team was able to secure tickets to the Ghibli Museum for me. These tickets are super popular and sell out quickly. Mind you, I made the same request to get tix using the Amex platinum concierge service and they were not able to fulfill it. When I went to thank the concierge team, I found out that a member of the team had to line up at Lawson and purchase them in person right after the tickets were available for sale. Lastly, I had many packages shipped to the hotel and the hotel lobby staff coordinated directly with me via email to ensure my packages arrived safely and stored properly until my arrival. Club lounge: as a platinum member, you will have access to the lounge. The lounge is fully stocked with lots of variety of drinks (soda, juice, tea, Perrier, Evian etc). There is also afternoon tea, during my previous visit we took advantage of this as my 3 year old daughter loved going there for afternoon tea and treats. You will not be disappointed with the lounge options here. Also, a must is to try the Japanese style breakfast. Lastly, to me what really distinguish a hotel’s service is the staff. The staff here is friendly, and if you make an effort to talk to them. They will always remember you and greet you by your name, which is something I always appreciate as they interact with hundreds of guests daily.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: This hotel was very nice and elegant. There was also a wonderful view of Mt. Fuji which was clearest in the early morning. The guest services were excellent as was the actual room, in which there were interesting controls to dim the window of the bathroom and cause it to become opaque with the touch of a button. It had a modern feel with a loft style setting in general.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: Don’t use email to communicate with them as they never reply. It’s a good hotel, very nice & clean but I think their service needs to be improved (especially this is 5 stars hotel in Japan). As a SPG Premier platinum member, I found the record of stays and nights are wrong when I saw the transaction via website. I email them (kioi-rsv@princehotels.co.jp) to correct but they just ignore my email after 5 days waiting. Before this trip, they normally reply my email after 3 days. This is a good hotel but far away from excellent hotel.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: All Tokyo Luxury hotels are solid for their excellent services, ultra clean rooms and great locations. Having stayed recently at Shangri-La / Mandarin Oriental who had their own advantages, I have to say Prince Gallery tops things in terms of services. Particularly from concierge. I came with two boys after skiing Hokkaido during the busy Christmas / New Year week with no plan ourselves at all other than the confidence in concierge to arrange a solid program for us. Shuta Takeuchi who speaks excellent English arranged train tickets to Hakone Hot Spring - two day free pass, movie tickets for my boys in addition to excellent choices of dining selections. This is the first trip for my sons to Tokyo and the 10 plus trip for me, and all of us enjoyed the city very much because of the hospitality of PG Kioicho. Happy New Year !

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: The hotel property is beautiful and the rooms are well designed to take in the breathtaking views of Tokyo. Unfortunately the service is only ok. I originally thought the poor service was due to the fact that our stay was timed during a busy period, but as we received poor service in multiple areas of the hotel- club lounge, housekeeping and restaurant - I believe there is a bigger issue.My high expectation for service was never met over a 4 day stay and as I paid close to $1,000 per night for 2 rooms I believe there is better value for money at other properties in Tokyo.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: I stayed here with my parents and my wife for our winter vacation.Staff service levels top notch, as expected for a hotel of this caliber.Location is great: a quiet, upscale neighborhood with very easy access to the subway.Rooms were new and clean. Fantastic views all directions (we stayed at three different directions through our two separate stays on this trip).Breakfast selection needs improvement. Maybe that’s just a Japanese thing. Specifically, Bread quality needs improvement, and cooked food selection should be wider.Pool looks great and gym has a good range of equipments.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: Room was modern and probably the most high-tech property I’ve been at. The window and view was incredible - I was able to see Mt Fuji! Service was top notch from the moment I got off the airport bus (which goes directly to this hotel) till checkout. Club lounge was great for quick breakfast + drinks. Lobby bar was fantastic too. Great atmosphere with music. Location wise, it’s in Akasaka which is much quieter than Ginza. Nevertheless, access to Ginza shopping is convenient via subway (directly underneath hotel). Lots of restaurants in the area. Would definitely come back next time.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: I really enjoyed my stay: I have been to Tokyo a number of times and as with many Asian locations for the global brands, the experience surpasses what you would get with the same brand in other parts of the world.This luxury collection opened since my last visit in 2016 and it was everything and more from what you would expect from a luxury collection, done Tokyo style:1. The hotel is typical of many in Tokyo: its in a high-rise whose reception area starts somewhere higher up in the high rise (in this case it was the 32nd or 34th floor). You can be guaranteed a view and daylight ), which is why I imagine they have the hotels start at a higher floor so the guest room views aren't blocked. I lucked out and could see into to Mount Fuji on the clear days.2. The service experience and the design is unparalleled:a) At check-in , the staff guides you and escorts you to the roomb) There were always adequate staff in the reception area exuding positive energy as you walked by. There was never a line for check-in or checkout. It seemed they knew how many people to staff at the desks when to get the desired effect.c) On the ground floor, there were sufficient staff members to help you as you got out of a cab, or help you get a cab. I always counted a minimum of 3.3. Health-club and pool facilities were spacious and large. I used the pool twice in the evening, and the health club every day in the morning. I could not sleep past 5am so workout seem to be a good idea to get the day underway. Even at the expected 'peak' time for 6:30am to 8am, they had sufficient equipment that there was never a wait. There was also a full benchpress in addition to the usual hotel equipment you would find. 4. This hotel pays a lot of attention to detail. Here are two examples:a) The safe had an electric outlet in case you wanted to charge your device while out of the roomb) The staff provided (by default) a set of power chargers in the desk to charge the most common devices. I didn't bother to open the bag, but I am convinced that if I had forgotten or lost my adapters, this would have been invaluable.5. Because of work commitments, I didn't get a chance to have a dinner here. But I did order in-room dining a number of times for breakfast. They were efficient and had light meals like smoothie or fruit6. The most important thing was after a long day was to just come unwind in the lobby area (which was half-way up the building height) and just relax, check e-mail in the open setting, and see the night time skylights from the 30+ floor.Highly recommended.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: Location, comfort, technology, service, cleanliness, space, gym, spa, decor, bar, cocktails, staff, sheets, kimonos, pajamas, slippers, bathroom extras, bar, cocktails, views...just that come to mind are 5 out of 5. Everything you see,smell, hear and feel are over the top.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: We’re SPG platinum and used our suite upgrades here. Definitely worth the upgrade. Suites are the largest I’ve stayed at in Tokyo. One of my favorites in Tokyo. Hotel comparisons: Park Hyatt - farther from subway, but equally luxurious and large suites. Andaz - similarly convenient location, suites are smaller. Hyatt Centric - awesome central Ginza location, smallest room and suite. Location: hotel is in Akasaka area of Tokyo, with lots of restaurants and shops within a short walk. Subway station is also convenient. Close to imperial palace. Main Entrance is a bit odd, cars drive through the garage (recessed from street) and pedestrian can walk out through the 4th floor, back side of entrance since hotel is on a slope.The subway is 3-5 mins walk through underground path and we took it to Shinjuku, Shibuya and Odaiba on different days. Super convenient. There’s a food court downstairs and a mini supermarket, very convenient. The location is just outside the main drag of food and bars, so it’s a lovely quiet location by the river. Lobby/rooms: at the top of the high rise building like many a Japan hotels. Modern and spacious. Service: hotel concierge emailed prior to my arrival to inquire about transportation needs and any other bookings they can help us with. Also a month prior, concierge assisted us in making dinner reservations at top restaurants in Tokyo.Club lounge: hotel has a club lounge on the 34th floor for premium guests. You can get platinum breakfast there or in the main restaurant. Suite: we were in a corner suite, same floor as the lobby. It’s the size of a NYC apt! The bedroom has a huge king bed, wrap around corner view of the city and window seat, desk area and a large sofa sitting around. A wall of closet. The suite has another room with the main living room and dining room (dining table seats 6-8 people). Decor is minimalist but warm.Bathrooms: there’s a powder room in the front hall, and a full bathroom attached to the bedroom. Huge space with double sinks, another wall of closets and a enormous modern Ofuro bathroom with bench inside. Separate toilet closet. Remede products were fabulous.If you’re unfamiliar with Ofuro bathroom, it’s basically a large fully enclosed room with a side by side shower and separate soaking tub. You shower and clean up with the shower, then when clean, enjoy a soak in the tub to relax and maybe sit on the bench to enjoy some steam. This would be same procedure if you visit an onsen (except it’s a large public tub).Breakfast buffet: mostly western style food with a lot of selections and includes made to order eggs, truffle omelet was decadent.We had a fabulous stay and would choose to stay here again next time we’re in Tokyo.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: My parents and I stayed 3 nights in the Princes Gallery. We were impressed by the stunning night city view when we got to the lobby located at level 36. We were checked in by a lovely lady who was real friendly and helped us out with all our needs. Our two rooms were very nice with panoramic view. The rooms were equipped with high tech from the toilet, the lamps, air conditioner, service request, curtain and blind which can be controlled from the side panel. All the staffs in the hotel were very professional, friendly and made the stay more enjoyable. Breakfast was okay with selections from Japanese and western food. The only downside was the lady who served us for breakfast during our stay. She always forgot our orders almost every morning. We had dinner at Washoku for the first night. The atmosphere was completely quiet, the service was polite but quite slow. The quality of sea urchin sushi is the best we’ve ever tasted.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: The Ritz Carlton of the 90's with impeccable service every time, every where, only at half the price. What a gem.Staff open the door, open the elevator, quietly do everything. The rooms are gorgeous as you look out over the gardens.The front desk went above and beyond helping us locate a missing bag that a car service left at Narita airport and made arrangements for us to retrieve it.The food/bar is excellent.Public areas are peaceful...not overwhelming like many other hotels.Most impressive!

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: Just like last time the view from the room was breath-taking, lighting in the room was bright, just as I like it, the bed wais comfortable, everything was simply spot on. Location is good, with underground stations nearby and many restaurants, cafes and small supermarkets downstairs.Staff was as good as I remembered, especially Mr Dai Miyaoka. He actually remembered me from over a year ago. The moment I stepped off the coach he recognized me and his face lit up. That was a most sincere welcome! His demeanour was respectful, discreet and yet genuine, a most delightful young man!

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: We ventured to Tokyo for a combination of my wife’s birthday and the Sakura blossoms and this visit elected to stay at the Prince Gallery. I will preface with saying we had a great overall stay and likely would not have any complaints if it were not one of if not the busiest week of the year. The front desk staff was welcoming and was able to get us in our rooms earlier than check in time which is always appreciated as a Platinum member. The concierge has nothing but amazing recommendations, pointing us to amazing restaurants from Sushi to Soba to street food. Great knowledge of the whole city kept us going all week. Like some other reviews, the whole no tattoo policy was inconvenient and seemingly dated (I understand the cultural reasons and precautions but still other Tokyo hotels of the same caliber don’t) and hard to abide by when they cover your ribs. The staff was nice though. The bar at the hotel is a beautiful overlook into the city and is a grandiose feature of design. The lobby restaurant had one of the largest breakfast buffets I’ve seen and this was not your getting cold type of food. Everything was fresh and being replaced continuously. The staff was attentive and serving your every need. It was also a plus the ground level had some venues for a quick bite or refreshment if you wanted to grab something on your way out. After check in our frustration with the front desk grew over the week due to seemingly forever wait times as there were a high volume of guests requiring assistance and a lot of VIPs that took away from the staff count. In the end it just left a bitter taste but its something I’d overlook on a return trip. Overall great time and would definitely return. Was super convenient to all parts of the city we wanted to spend time in.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: Hotel on the top floors of a building that is in a great area, close to several subway stations and a really cool area of bars and restaurants. The hotel bar is stunning and has a great liquor selection. Breakfast really good, gym is very nice and while I didn’t swim due to a law making swimming caps required. Not cheap but worth the money, o and the Toto toilets are awesome.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: Good location, great view, room is big enough but I had a club deluxe with access to club room for breakfast and aperitifs People really paid attention to my needs but breakfast is better in the main room rather than the club except for the service which is better at the clubThe view is really amazing from the hotel located at the top floors of the building Easy access to main places through the subway next to the hotel. A place I am willing to come back during my next trip in Tokyo

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: Stayed for a few nights before leaving Tokyo and did not want to leave. The rooms - amazing, clean, modern, smart technology, Japanese layout with so many hidden things and superb viewsService - unmatched from check in to check out. Breakfast was a bit slow due to volume, but small thingLocation is great, maybe a bit of a walk to the train, but normal for Tokyo It could be a bit pricey, but its worth it. Highly recommended, and after you experience the turn-down service you will want to return :)

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: I stayed at this hotel for 5 nights and i might say was one of the most amazing hotels i have stayed. The room was spacious which is kind of rare in Japan. The room was situated in the 32-th floor and had an amazing view over the city. The coolest thing was the hi tech furniture, it had a tablet too to control every thing in the room. The spa and gym was perfect. The staff as a matter of fact in every other place in Japan were really very helpful and friendly. Definitely worth the money.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: Amazing hotel. Ulta modern, new, clean, and quiet. Staff is most professional and kind. Rooms are large with every convenience and bathroom with shower stunning. Only complaint is the restaurant on the lobby floor of the hotel. The food needs improvement, it was our worst meal in Japan. If the hotel overhauled the standards at the restaurant, the hotel would be faultless.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: With 2 weeks work in Tokyo I chose to stay at the Prince Gallery as ironically it was the only booking I could find.Our arrival and in-boarding was smooth - but we were initially confused about the lobby on the 36 floor.The rooms (we had a double) are amazing.The views in the evening give a really nice Tokyo skyline, however it is the sunrise that is better.The bathroom was the best I have ever seen in any hotel. I already miss it.The only slight downside to all this luxury is of course cost...

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: Our last night in Japan (after two weeks) we spent one night in this hotel... frankly, it surpassed our expectations in every way. Our room was spacious and over-the-top modern, with touch control window blnds. The bathroom was huge and enclosed in glass, and the toiletries were suplime. THE VIEWS... wow! Only negative was the busy business location and the relative inexperience of the young staff-- the check in experience was not up to the same level as other luxury hotels we've stayed in. BUT real relative value compared to other Tokyo five stars, and we HIGHLY RECOMMEND.
user_name:
cassidy24
New York City, New York

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: During our recent Tokyo trip we (two adults and two children) chose to stay at Prince Gallery again. This was our third stay there and this time we brought along friends too. We stayed in a corner suite on the executive floor and our friends (two couples) stayed in two different rooms on the same floor. Nothing much had changed since our last visit, except the location of the business centre had been moved to the opposite room. Our favourite corner suite, with its gorgeous wet room, was impressive as always. Service was impeccable. It was our friends’ first stay at Prince Gallery and they were impressed by the views from the main lobby and their rooms, the breakfast and the fitness centre. The swimming pool was not big but a morning swim there was always enjoyable. The staff of the fitness centre provided very friendly service, including but not limited to taking the initiative to offer me goggles and cap. The only “worry” of ours is that we hope its suites/rooms are not yet fully booked and won’t be too expensive for the Tokyo Olympics 2020!

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: I've stayed two nights at The Prince Gallery and loved the modern decor and the view from the room and public spaces.Good check in experience and as a Spg gold member I got an upgrade to a Tokyo Sky tree view room. Great view from the lobby at 36° floor and the bar.The deluxe king room had modern decor and amenities; Ipad for controlling everything in the room ie lights, air conditioning, curtains. Big lcd HD tvThe view from the room over Tokyo skyscrapers is amazing! Loved it.There is a pijama and a Yukata available, tea making facilities, minibar and Nespresso machine.The bathroom is divided from the room by a trasparent glass that dimmers for privacy; There are Remede toiletries, walk in shower and full immersion bath tub, fluffy bathrobes, and Toto toilet.Really appreciated the smoking room inside the hotel near the lobby.Big breakfast buffet, good food variety and good service. The view from the breakfast restaurant is amazing.The only big downside, that in part ruined my experience, was the visit at the Spa/pool, there is a no tattoo rule so the staff provided some stickers to put on the tattos but it was a real putt off, first of all the stickers would be ok for small tattoos if someone has an arm, leg or a bigger tattoo it's a problem,then if someone has hairs on his body the stickers would not attach good and I don't tell you when you have to wash it off...it's not easy and a little painfull. The pool staff was professional and apologised for my big disappointment since my partner did not had the chance to have a bath and I had to fight to put the stickers off my arm.I really understand the tattoo rule but not in a 5* hotel that caters international clients (whom are surerely not a Jakuza member), and since I can't go to the pool with visible tattoos why can I be allowed to walk around the hotel?...it does not make much sense. I've had this tattoo issue only at The Prince Gallery, in the other hotels visited in Tokyo (Conrad, Shangrila) I had no problems at all using their spa and pool facilities.Underground for moving around Tokyo is next to the hotel.A part from the pool problem i really liked the Prince Gallery, but don't know if I would be back if this rule goes on.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: The room I had - which I upgraded to a junior suite - was great. The rooms of my friends were way smaller and I would have suffocated The space is lovely, they try and act like they care but the reality is they don’t Not impressed at all at the service - including ringing the door bell when one is asleep with do not disturb onNice space - kind of - but not even in the same league as any of the top hotels So many dreadful moments but frankly do not care as I will never stay there again

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: I stayed at the Prince Galley Hotel for 4 nights and was really throughly impressed with the overall stay. I would say that it's from the airport to the hotel is not too bad although not direct by train unless you're taking an uber or taxi.It's situated right by a couple of subway station which gives you the flexibility to travel around Tokyo. I really liked the room and it's modern technology. Very spacious and multiple USB ports. The gym is nice and has a lot of technogym machines you can use!The only negative (Why -1 star but -0.5 star) I have about the hotel is the lounge especially for the evening service. Not much in terms of hot food or variety (the same each night) and wished that there was more.But overall would stay again!

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: I didn’t stay here but my colleague did and I wish I had. The rooms are outstanding, service is excellent and a Negroni at the bar 36 stories up is worth it alone. We had very good tepanyaki, worth the money!!

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: Wonderful hotel in a great location. The shower is a dream, especially with the humidity of Tokyo. Room is a little small, but top notch amenities in it. Bar and lobby are at the top of the building, making for some fantastic views. Service is excellent. Building has access to two subway stations, which covers at least 4 different lines so you can get anywhere quick. Building also has restaurants, shopping, and a nice grocery store. Pool is nice, but they make you wear a swim cap, which seems odd to me.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: This is an absolute stunner of a hotel. Situated adjacent to the prime business district it sits on the top floors of a a commercial estate which houses multiple restaurants and access to the subway. The rooms are sublime. Modern, technologically connected, and the views are absolutely breath taking. Gym is open 24 hours. Pool has a great view of Tokyo city. I have stayed here for the last 3 visits and will continue to choose this beautiful SPG hotel for my next visit to Tokyo!

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: The hotel is new and beautifully designed with 5 star facilities including state of the art gym, pool and sauna. The room is of good size (with a big bath tub) and the bed is very comfortable. As with most (Japanese 5 star hotels), the room was impeccably cleaned (and stocked with good quality toiletries, Japanese PJs, bathroom, slippers, tea, coffee and good mini bar) and staff are professional. Because the hotelis located on top of a business building it has great views of Tokyo. The breakfast pricing is on the more expensive side but it is of good quality. The bar has a good atmosphere and great views of Tokyo - recommend having a drink there. The only negative side of this hotel is it’s location - there is about a 10 mins walk to the train station from the hotel and there are not many shops around the hotel. Overall, enjoyed my stay there very much and looking forward to returning in the near future.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: I tried to arrange an airport pickup through the PG hotel. At first they sent me details on how to catch a bus, so I called again (in fact the concierge at the HK Marriott called them for me, as he thought this would reduce the likelihood of any misunderstanding). This time they confirmed a hotel car pick-up to him and sent me an email asking for me to fill in a paper form, photocopy a copy of my credit card and send it back to them. So the Marriott concierge called them again, advising them that they already had my cc on file for my room booking. They told him it was ‘hotel policy’ that I complete the form, sign it, photocopy my cc etc etc; so I did!The PG concierge then emailed me to say that they didn’t in fact have any cars available, but would instead arrange for a taxi to meet me. I’ve just arrived at Haneda and no taxi, so I called the hotel and they advised me that they haven’t arranged anything. I’m now in a very long queue for a taxi!Appreciate this is a first world problem, but with the prices the PG charges I would expect first world service.BTW - stay at the JW Marriott in Hong Kong - it’s excellent.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: If you are looking for a higher end Hotel in Tokyo at a fairly decent price then this is a good pick. 4.5 rounded up to 5.First impression: 4.5 Stars , greeted immediately by friendly valet staff. Must take elevator to 36th floor. Nice view from main lobby.Check-in: 4.5 Stars - Room was ready upon arrival, check-in was quick. Didn’t acknowledge our special occasion, although there was something in our room for us. We were escorted to the room by a member of the front desk team who gave us an overview of the room.Room: 4 Stars - Beautiful picture window with nice seating in front. King Bed, very modern. Single vanity, full length mirror. No light switches, everything goes through iPad or control center by bed. Toto toilet, with automatic toilet seat. Bed was comfortable. Bathroom vanity area was small. Spa: 4 Stars - pool heated, more of a lap pool than a lounge pool. Small Co-ed jacuzzi overlooking Tokyo, nice gym. Steam and Sauna in male and female locker rooms. Nice but not luxurious.Spa treatment: 5 Stars - 60 minute massage, excellent. Concierge: 4 Stars - not very helpful with questions. Did not advise us properly on train tickets. Location : 5 Stars - 15 minute walk to imperial palace and garden. Dean and Deluca coffee at the entrance of the hotel. Starbucks, and Lawson convenience store also at the entrance. Convenient central location to all of Tokyo. Dining/Bar/Breakfast: N/A lobby bar has nice view over Tokyo Check-out : 5 Stars Quick & standardThe one thing I didn’t like about this property was the fact that you had to take 2 different elevators when going to your room. From the entrance you must take the elevator to the 36th floor and then walk across the lobby and take another elevator down to your room. Overall my wife and I enjoyed our stay here and would recommend to others looking for a hotel in Tokyo with a luxury feel at a fair price.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: We stay here as a family of 4 in the Club Deluxe Premier room and we all thoroughly enjoyed our time (3 nights) at this hotel. We spend a lot of our time out and about so didn't really get the chance to try most of the facilities with the exception of the club lounge.Our room and generally the hotel is very clean, room is spacious, modern (hi tech) where you can control most of the room (curtains, lights etc) via the ipad. The amenities are good quality and bathroom are decent sized too.Club lounge is very modern and relatively small (Im guessing it fits up about 30-40 guests), whilst the quality of the food is good the selection is limited due to the size of the lounge nonetheless we felt it was more intimate. Location of the hotel is good as it is within 5 min walk to the nearest train station. Furthermore, there are plenty of restaurants/ cafe in the same building down towards the ground floor which makes it very convenient if you do not want to always dine in the hotel.Staff were all very friendly, helpful and well spoken. At no point did we felt communication was an issue. All request was promptly attended to.What we found unusual is that apparently children are not allowed in the pool, and the club lounge access during the evening canapes period is strictly adults only. So families please be informed so you are not disappointed during your stay.We felt it is good value for money, and would definitely consider staying here again when we return to Tokyo next time.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: Stayed for a one night R&R break. Very modern hotel occupying the top few floors of an office block. Interestingly the reception is on the top floor (36) and you go down to your rooms. The rooms are very specious and full of tech. Everything can be operated by the iPad located by the side of the bed - Full range of lighting, windows blinds/shades, a/c etc. Bed is very comfortable. PlusesLocation - a few minutes from two subway stations. Room - see aboveSpa/pool - very Japanese so research the etiquette first. MinusesCheck in time- was kept waiting for 10 minutes while then reception staff sorted out the room. Breakfast - I look forward to breakfast in hotels but this was just a bit bland. Plus very crowded. Cost - not sure it represented good value.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: A relaxing and comfortable stay in a modern and high-technological hotel with a comfortable room and bed.It was a very nice view from the lounge on the 34th floor and the fitness area with sauna was great.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: We spontaneously decided to take a 5 night trip to visit Tokyo for the first time and only booked 48 hours prior to departing via our online Starwood SPG membership.The luxury hotel was the first Starwood hotel for Tokyo city and is in Chiyoda-Ku, Akasaka which opened in mid August 2016 and is located up from the 36th floor taking up the top 7 levels of the building. The hotel comes under Luxury Collection for SPG Starwood which all hotels have merged in August under the major brand group of the Marriott.There are spectacular views of Tokyo from all room types due to the fact the hotel starts from the 36th level and no other building to obstruct it. There is a glass sliding door on each level after you exit the lift where you need to swipe your key card for added security to the guest to their rooms. We had a Deluxe King Room facing over Akasaka Chiyoda-ku shopping district and restaurant precinct. The rooms are exceptionally clean and very well maintained, quite spacious and modern in contemporary design. Our king bed felt bigger than normal was very comfortable, it also had a long window seat to sit and lay down and enjoy the view and I believe all room types have similar. The block out blind and curtain are electronically controlled so you don't even have to move out of bed. The shower and bath area has two glass walls allowing natural light in where you don't feel enclosed in a room, however with a flick of switch the glass becomes obscure for privacy, they're appointed with beautiful white grey marble and stainless fixtures!!! The toilet light comes on as you enter with the toilet lid slowly raising itself up and or down with motion senses. The amenities selection in the bathroom to be honest I have never seen so many and the quality was very good. Massive television screen, great coffee station along with snacks and mini bar if you're into that sort of thing. Every night we had a little bag of macaroons left for turn down service which was lovely. Beautiful Asian style robes to wear as well, however when you have a husband who is 6ft tall and has broad shoulders it posed a little problem.All the staff were exceptionally polite as Japanese people are always and they were most helpful with any questions we had from directions, tours basically everything. Some of their English was good however you need slow down for some so they're able to understand because our accent even though we speak perfect English sounds in a different way to them but thats normal for a lot of countries and not an issue.The Oasis Garden restuarant has all day dining and where we had our buffet breakfast everyday. There is also a Japanese restaurant Washoku Souten located on the lower level by stairs for full traditional Asian breakfast. Oasis Garden restaurant food quality and selection was very good and caters very well for westerners and also has asian dishes including traditional asian style breakfast. As the restuarant takes up half of the 36th level it has three side viewing aspects, we sat in a different side each morning to take in each of the spectacular views over Tokyo. A few mornings at breakfast was a little chaotic at the peak time of 9 to 9.30am where one of the staff members was a little overwhelmed with so many people but that was the only issue we had for our entire stay. If you can go earlier for breakfast do so as we found 8 to 8.30am made a difference of less crowding. We only dined in the hotel for breakfast as we wanted to experience Tokyo at other meal times. In regards to in room dining we did try one evening due to returning back very late at night from a Mt Fuji all day trip and to be honest didn't like the menu, I suppose because wasn't enough western choices.The Akasaka-Mitsuke subway train is only 5 minute walk across the road from the hotel building and the best way to get around Tokyo. The famous Shibuya is about a 10 minute subway ride and a few minutes more after a change to the JR Line above ground train to Harajuku. Akasaka has a huge selection of restuarants only five minutes away from Japanese, Italian, French, Korean, Seafood and Sushi choices. There are a few convenience stores 5 minutes away as well for anything you might need as well as a major shopping centre if you're needing something really close by.Overall we had a wonderful, luxury stay and highly recommend the hotel and will return again very soon!!!

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: So far the best hotel we've stayed at in Tokyo, and that's saying a lot considering how the city is so full of great hotels. Don't need to say much other than the staff is outstanding and the rooms are impressive with the most comfortable beds we've slept in in a while. But the hallmark of a great hotel is attention to details and this place has few comparisons -- not a spec of dust anywhere for instance. The hotel deserves 6 stars if there could be such.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: The hotel has "almost" nothing to criticize - certainly my latest favorite in Tokyo. Rooms are very well appointed with spectacular windows and views and of course the service is excellent. The pool and spa are excellent too however, there are a few disappointments but they are for the moment overshadowed by the positives. The Executive Lounge is too small and the food/drink options unfortunately too limited. The breakfast is good but unfortunately also not a wow.... The real issue they need to reconsider is the wall lighting in the main bar - my colleagues and I all found it actually visually disturbing. Having said that we all loved staying at this new hotel - we just had cocktails elsewhere.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho is a SPG member hotel of the Luxury Collection brand, the room layout is beautiful, the decor is both contemporary and vivid in color. Breakfast is great with three different kinds: Japanese, American and buffet, they are all good. On top of all this, this hotel has a most convenient location with two subway lines underneath the same building (exit from F2), and one just about 100 feet across the street which can get you pretty much everywhere in the city of Tokyo and get to the NRT airport through the Keisei line. Two thumbs up!

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: I have travelled to Japan many times due to work and pleasure. What made me stay at this hotel this trip was mainly because of Mr. Shuta Takeuchi from the Concierge desk. He went over the top in helping me to secure reservations from hard-to-book restaurants and even golf course as a single player. He was always proactive in his suggestions and extremely responsive (usually replied within the same day). This is a big contrast to some of the other 5 star hotels I stayed before in Japan which they tend to offer cookie-cutter suggestions and don't think outside the box.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: Amazing room, amazing view, amazing facilities and amazing staff. Ive stayed here about 4 times before and it has never disappointed up till now. I felt like an inmate in a prison where my rice was as cold and hard. Nevertheless it;s an amazing hotel with excellent staff. Maybe the chef wasnt in a good mood. A video of this will be added soon. By the way, there isnt a difference whether youre a Marriott or SPG member when it comes to room service.

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: The service is very good as you expect from Japanese hotels. The view is what makes breathtaking in this hotel. In the room or at the bar, the view of the city is just amazing. Attention to allergy is taken very seriously for room cleaning, it was much appreciated. Strongly recommend

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: The Prince Gallery Tokyo provides well trained professional service, brilliantly engineered and appointed rooms, and a great view of the fantastic city of Tokyo. The Akasaka section of the city has plenty to offer and is a bit quieter than the more touristy Ginza area. Many restaurants in the building and on the local area within walking distance. The hotel is Pricey- but not sticker shock level. Top recommendations!!

hotel_name: The Prince Gallery Tokyo Kioicho, A Luxury Collection Hotel
review_body: We were in Tokyo for the Ayumi Hamasaki 20th anniversary concert, en route to Mt. Fiji. We decided to stay at Prince Kiochio based on its great reviews and our Starwood SPG gold status. There were many nice things about the Prince Kiochio property. The grounds are lovely and adjacent to many convenient stores and restaurants. We booked a standard club room, which was surprisingly spacious and comfortable and had beautiful views of the Tokyo Tower and the city skyline. The room was very modern and cool, and the highlights were the awesome window seat and the privacy glass of the bathroom (so cool!). The club lounge was comfortable and had an excellent selection of snacks and liquors. However, despite these niceties, there were many problems with our stay. The biggest problem was that a lot of the staff seemed cold and impersonable, more so than any where else we stayed in Japan. We drove to the hotel in the late evening after the Ayu concert, and there was no coordination between the valet and the front desk to give us a white glove welcome to the hotel. We were not escorted to our suite on arrival, and we were not offered any welcome refreshments. Though the room we booked was comfortable, we were surprised that we were not offered a room or suite upgrade and not given any membership gifts. At breakfast, the staff was not attentive, and acted as if they were annoyed at our requests and only came by if we literally stood up and flagged the staff down. My husband used the shoe shine service (supposedly shoes are returned same day)— no one returned his shoes and he finally had to call for return since we were checking out. Housekeeping staff walked into our room twice, merely because the “do not disturb” light was off — I’ve never stayed at a resort or hotel where the housekeeping manager didn’t call first to double check, if the guests were known to still be on the property! And it seemed like there was zero communication between the desk, club lounge and car port to retrieve/deliver our car while we were there. The club lounge desk staff was polite enough, but like the front desk reception, did zero to add to or assist our stay. The service, concierge and reception paled in comparison to our subsequent stays at the Tokyo Four Seasons and Hoshinoya, as well as our stays at other 4 and 5-star properties in our trip across Japan. Check out Instagram for more photos and videos of our luxury hotel reviews @lifestylesofthenickandnikki!
